Blues Harp

Inspired by the Blues bars of london, I had decided to take up the Harmonica. On Christmas morning I unwrapped a beautiful metal instrument, and blew my first note.

Sadly, I quickly realised it was far too cumbersome to carry. My pockets were already full of my phone, wallet and keys. I searched for a more portable solution. The pebble {code} music hack day provided me with the inspiration I needed to create a new musical object I could access anywhere. The digital Blues Harp was born.

In one day, I designed, coded and performed on this new instrument, powered by the Wad.JS library and a dash of JQuery. Amazingly, the performance won me the hack day!

Move your mouse or touch device screen to play.

Play the harp GitHub Repo

Sow & Grow

In 2015 I had two aims. Firstly, I wanted to improve my JavaScript knowledge. Secondly, I wanted to sample the delights of home grow vegetables in my dinner.

When I found the existing resources on growing vegetables to be lacklustre, I decided to create this app to help fulfil my needs. I gathered data from various resources, and got to work. As the codebase grew larger, so did my crops. You can watch my presentation on the whole experience below.

Let's grow! GitHub Repo

Emoti

How would you visualise the Emotional state of the world? At #ArtHackathon2015, our team of artists and designers created a possible solution, in the form of a light and sound installation, powered by tweets.

Using the Twitter post fetcher, I altered the colours and music of a webpage according to each emotional response of tweets, in real time. This was then visualised on the browser of a Raspberry Pi. Using lazer-cut acryclic mounted on to an LED screen, a glowing, morphing sculpture was created. The 3D version has been dismantled (for now), but feel free to check out the code behind it.

GitHub Repo

Whisky Map

As I say sipping the golden spirit in my glass, my mind wandered to the landscapes of Scotland...land of my forefathers.

Unfortunately, I had no clue where this particular drink originated from, so the image in my mind was left incomplete. Nothing but a blurred scene of peaty waters and drizzle.

Lucky for me, the pebble {code} data visualisation hack day encouraged me explore a solution. In 8 hours I gathered a data set of Single Malt flavours, the D3 Javas4cript library and mixed it up with a dash of Leaflet, an open-source mapping library. Take a look at the results for yourself...

Explore Scotland

Guess Hex

Another day, another pebble {code} hack day. This time, the theme was gaming. I chose to build a mobile friendly colour matching game, using JQuery Mobile.

To win, you have to try and convert Hex to HSL in your head, and move the sliders to the right combination. The closer the match, the higher the score.

Test my hex skills GitHub Repo

Attain

It was the weekend of the Sci Fi London 2015 24h film competition. We had the beginnings of a story of a dystopian existence in which companies could access the minds of willing people. The company - Attain - needed a brand and an interface for it's users.

While the team finalised the scripts I fleshed out a design for the Attain UI that could be used captured on camera that same afternoon.

(Only designed for desktop - for faster prototyping, some elements were dropped in as SVG's)

Access Attain GitHub Repo

Agile Metrics App

A pebble {code} client project. As the client continued it's Agile transformation, managers wanted a tool for monitoring indivisual team progress at working agile.

We hosted a workshop to define the requirements of this system, from the user's perspective. We defined an MVP and set to work with production.

Using node & ReactJS, the developers & I built a mobile first, interactive assessment tool. Teams could view their quaterly progress through D3 charts, and store key notes with their report. An admin section allowed addition and organisation of teams on the system, as well as controlling user access.

App currently being trialled with teams.
